51.49.text:
that kind of sums the ten years of Irish history
between 1912 and 1922,

56.30.text:
it's this rather ugly artillery gun,
and the humble 18-pounder artillery shell.

60.32.text:
It's one of those objects
that has a big impact on our history.

64.11.text:
Many Irishmen served in the British Army
using that particular weapon on the Western Front.

74.31.text:
It's used in the 1916 rising -
four of them were used to bombard the city

77.55.text: and they caused huge damage to the city.

80.12.text:
And then our own civil war starts
when two of those guns were used

82.98.text:
to bombard anti-treaty forces
during the summer of 1922.

89.16.text:
The great myth of the 1916 rising is that
the British Army had loads of artillery

93.37.text:
There were actually only eight artillery guns 
in Ireland during Easter 1916.

97.38.text:
All the guns that the British Army had were in 
France getting ready for the Somme operation,

101.99.text:
which we now know about,
but at that time was a big secret.

104.73.text:
Out of the eight guns, four were broken,
and only four were actually working.

109.14.text:
The city was actually bombarded -
what you're seeing is a desperate operation

113.04.text:
by the Royal Artillery to get
their four guns into the city.

116.05.text:
The shell that they're using
is an 18-pounder shell,

118.31.text:
which in those days was a shrapnel shell,
it wasn't high-explosive.

121.28.text:
It was designed to kill 
soldiers out in the open.

124.78.text:
So in the urban setting not 
a very effective weapon,

127.09.text: but very striking, and then very loud.

131.88.text:
But what does happen is, 
over a period of time,

137.84.text:
The fires are started by the artillery -
not by the shells, but by knocking down oil lamps,

142.84.text:
knocking into buildings 
which have flammable material.

145.43.text:
Looters who take over the city centre
and start looting the shops

149.96.text:
And then the rebels start to 
burn down several buildings

151.79.text: as a way of containing the British Army.

153.54.text:
And what you get is all of those 
three aspects coming together

156.15.text: to kind of destroy the centre of the city

157.96.text: and causing £2 million worth of damage.

160.90.text:
As well as the executions, 
it's the big visual thing

162.90.text: that people remember from the rising,

The second object then was 
the Irish Republic flag,

and a photograph of British Army officers

who would have recruited mainly in Kilkenny,

so predominately Roman Catholics

This is the thing about the rising,
is that in the initial stages of the rising,

193.78.text:
it's very much, in the first two days,
Irishmen fighting Irishmen.

197.16.text: And that's just the spoils of war.

Out of that photograph only about 
five or six

206.33.text:
of the officers actually

They're going off to fight in

210.63.text:
the chances of them actually seeing

212.38.text:
as officers with the high casualty rate

When I look at the photograph

These men have joined up,

If you take an oath to the rebels,

248.43.text:
The reason why that interests me is just that 
contemporary documents of what it was like

251.13.text: to be during the rising are very rare.

252.91.text:
We're reliant on personal letters, 
diaries of people

255.58.text:
to kind of find out what people's opinion
was on the street.

259.41.text:
Newspapers aren't publishing during this time,
there's a sense of fear.

262.90.text:
What I liked about the diary is that you get
this kind of sense of gossip,

266.22.text:
rumour and milling around the city,
very little information coming out,

270.17.text:
and a huge fear that the rebels 
had turned out

274.79.text:
that was going to cause destruction,

279.54.text:
And in documents I've read from the period, that

was the same as it was in 1916 -

1916 causes both communities to 
kind of go back

VIVIENNE POLLOCK: This kind of personal testimony

303.50.text:
a very important part of the historical evidence
and the historical context for these great events,

310.86.text:
which sometimes I think we forget
they actually involved real people.

314.92.text:
And this is very much a person
who was in Dublin for other reasons.

320.65.text:
It reflects a civilian's viewpoint and
experiences through the rising.

327.37.text:
And it's also a female voice, 
and female voices are

330.29.text: really quite rare in this type of history.

334.28.text:
I think the first thing that struck me
was 'we scoffed',

338.94.text:
and that's almost within
the first sentence of the diary.

343.28.text:
And I think that underpins the derision of
the events

351.11.text: There is an undercurrent of unease and anxiety.

356.79.text:
It's a very short diary,
it's only four or five, six days I think,

362.40.text: from the Sunday to the following Saturday.

366.88.text:
It opens with this derision

371.57.text:
I think that's quite a profound 
topping and tailing

375.52.text:
of really quite a short space of time

386.84.text:
The postcards are interesting
because to me they demonstrate news.

392.78.text:
I don't think they're 
particularly celebratory,

395.57.text:
and I don't think they're 
particularly commemorative.

399.57.text:
They are a medium that was 
increasingly used by 1910,

405.67.text: the early 20th century, to convey news.

409.57.text:
And this is part of a pattern really that...
and again it's associated with photography,

415.40.text:
it's associated with improvements 
in print technology,

423.67.text:
But the Daily Sketch was the soldiers' newspaper

so the Daily Sketch would have produced

There were numerous sets of postcards produced

and the Carson Trail and anti-Home Rule postcards,

I think they're very much on a par with the use of

451.95.text:
to bring events to people...
and to make money!

456.50.text:
I think we've got to remember that there was 
a commercial aspect to these as well.

463.11.text:
Printers were really quite astute in seeing
an opportunity to set up a print run

468.36.text: and to seize a commercial opportunity.

473.54.text:
You know, we think we live in
an age of instant communications,

476.44.text:
and in a way we do,

481.02.text: you know, in the early 20th century,

483.79.text:
the postal service and communications and
newspapers and

487.23.text:
particularly the use of illustrations and
visual material.

It didn't take days and months for this sort

496.20.text: Sometimes they could get them out within hours.

498.15.text:
Some of them look staged to me,

But because of the context, you know,
and the destruction and particularly the passers-by,

509.03.text:
I would be happy enough, 
I would be confident enough,

really quite soon after the events

I think the brooch is interesting 
for two reasons.

530.80.text:
It has a macabre provenance.
It was part of a soldier's loot

537.66.text:
that almost brings in the brutality and
the callousness that was very, very much present

543.68.text:
within events in Dublin at that time,
I think on all sides.

549.07.text:
It's based on what we call a penannular brooch,

557.75.text:
It's not confined to Ireland,
but it became really connected with Ireland

561.62.text: with the discovery of the Tara Brooch in 1850.

568.28.text: It's not a particularly high-quality object.

573.22.text:
Was it a sweetheart brooch? 
I mean, that's almost

575.12.text: the first thing that struck me.

578.57.text:
So it's a personal thing, 
but it's a commercial thing,

582.67.text: and it is quite a sinister war trophy thing.

So, it's quite interesting how you can have
the mundane and the personal

wrapped up into really what is an insignificant,
